tweets.text: And the @EnvAgency does what exactly? https://t.co/bNAXQbWW1G

We‚Äôre working with @WTBBC and @BhamCityCouncil on improvements to R.Cole in #Birmingham. Just completed an area through #BordesleyGreen  creating a meander, marginal shelves & in-channel habitat in a straightened section of river. Volunteers to plant shelves with native species https://t.co/MCPO1nVy9O

@The26thchoice1 @worcscc @Wychavon @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgencyMids @CllrAHardman @HWFireControl We closed the bridge earlier as advised - it's possible that signs have been removed - we're sending an inspector to check - the bridge is officially closed & we do not recommend that anyone attempts to cross - please advise source of local information
‚õîÔ∏è We are in the process of closing Eckington Bridge https://t.co/x0M1yeeHdb

If you use a domestic heating #OilTank, you need to make sure it's in a good condition before ordering more oil.

If your tank has a crack, you could endanger the environment and our drinking water supplies.

Retweet this message to let more people know. https://t.co/HsbP3JHD0Y

tweets.text:
Just 6 months after admitting to 8,400 pollution incidents in court @SouthernWater still manage to top the 2019 polluter in chief scoreboard.

What's clear is the @EnvAgency has no control over this company and even clearer, it is now time for @Ofwat to revoke SW's licence. https://t.co/1KqXjd6XYE

It's Monday, must be time for another @EnvAgency failure.

"Farmers on average receive a pollution inspection from the Environment Agency every 263 years.

https://t.co/VMQ2CkIp4M

Out of interest, this farmer would likely be eligible for Woods for Water funding through the @ForestryComm and @EnvAgencyYNE, paying for new fences and woodland to give an even greater buffer and prevent sedimentation and runoff. FC Woodland Officers can provide more info. https://t.co/aubAvjftXz

We‚Äôve completed our maintenance works on the Rivers Loxley, Don and Dearne in #Sheffield.  Local #flood risk has been reduced and the remaining gravels provide beneficial aquatic habitat. Here's a before and after of the work at #Hillsborough. #WinterReady https://t.co/S9FovrxvMD https://t.co/XuarsIf9dE

urls.title: Is it flooded now? River levels in York
urls.description: Data here is updated every 20 minutes or so from the river level at the River Ouse Viking station. Please use your own judgement - the measures are approximate, occasional data errors are inevitable and paths may still be unusably silted even if they are clear of water. The heights were composed from reports by people on Twitter (the #YorkCyclingFloods hashtag is good for this). If you can add or correct routes then tweet me @nose_army.

tweets.text:
Good Morning #York!
You've probably been expecting it with all this rain and #StormAlex; New Walk is now flooded and the Lendal Bridge flood barriers are shut.
Check https://t.co/5EFzEez3eA for updates and share your own with #yorkcyclingfloods https://t.co/Hn6809gMlK

Lunt Meadows NR is closed closed until further notice. River Alt has overtopped at the spillway as per design but has breached at 2 further points undermining the bank. Visitors should not enter from any entrance & especially not walk on the river bank @EnvAgency  @LivEchonews https://t.co/JSybmCojnd

Supermarkets, food manufacturers and restaurant chains under pressure from campaigners over their environmental impact are urging Britain to strengthen a plan to stop tropical forests from being cut down to grow cocoa, palm oil and soy https://t.co/1FENW5fPwj https://t.co/9eksp3WMiX

entity.name: Countryfile
entity.description: Stories are shared of the people, places and issues at the heart of the British countryside. Popular features include the programme's photography contest, which culminates in a yearly calendar sold to benefit charity, the Video Diary, produced by viewers and focused on life in rural areas, and the weather forecasts.

domain.name: TV Shows
domain.description: Television shows from around the world

entity.name: Countryfile Diaries
entity.description: A sister show to the BBC's `Countryfile' series, this rural affairs programme sees a team of presenters travel the length and breadth of the United Kingdom to cover stories related to the British countryside and the season of spring. As this period is a busy time of the year for the farming and outdoor communities in particular, regular topics covered include the production of food, nature conservation, and a look at a chosen area's culture and history. Stunning landscapes and a variety of wildlife also feature prominently.
